case_data.name: Saddozai v. Davis
case_data.plaintiff_description: A prisoner at San Quentin State Prison.
case_data.summary:
This case involved allegations of excessive force by a correctional officer. On September 11, 2018, a prisoner in San Quentin State Prison filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California against a correctional officer in San Quentin State Prison under 42 U.S.C. § 1983. Originally filing pro se, the plaintiff alleged that he was attacked by other incarcerated individuals when the defendant correctional officer intervened by shooting the plaintiff several times. The plaintiff sought declaratory and injunctive relief as well as compensatory and punitive damages. The case was assigned to Judge Beth Labson Freeman.

Following the court’s dismissal of the complaint with leave to amend on January 16, 2019, on February 19, 2019, the plaintiff filed an amended complaint with additional factual allegations and attachments. 

On July 11th, 2019 the court dismissed the complaint with leave to amend for the plaintiff to file an amended complaint that complied with Rules 18(a) and 20(a) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. On August 15, 2019, the plaintiff filed a second amended complaint.

On March 2, 2020, the defendant filed a motion to dismiss the plaintiff’s second amended complaint. On March 6, 2020, the plaintiff filed a third amended complaint adding claims against the warden and the Director of the CDCR based on supervisor liability. 

The defendant moved to dismiss this complaint, which the court denied as moot on April 23rd, 2020. The court ordered that the third amended complaint was the operative complaint in this matter under Rule 15(a)(1)(B). On the same day, the court denied plaintiff’s fourth motion for appointment of counsel and granted plaintiff’s motion for extension of time to complete discovery. 

On December 2nd, 2020, the court granted the defendant's motion to dismiss for failure to exhaust administrative remedies, saying that the defendant had shown that there was an available administrative remedy and the plaintiff did not exhaust that available administrative remedy before he filed the action, though he had since. The court also ruled that the additional claims in the third amended complaint allegations were insufficient to support a claim of supervisor liability and dismissed them without leave to amend. 

On December 28, 2020, the plaintiff filed a notice of appeal to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals. 

On May 23rd, 2022, the panel reversed the district court’s dismissal for lack of exhaustion and remanded, clarifying Jackson v. Fong’s holding that a prisoner who has fully complied with the PLRA’s exhaustion requirement does not need to file a new complaint simply because he had not exhausted when he filed his original federal complaint.

 On June 17, 2024, the Court granted the defendants’ motion for terminating sanctions. The Court found that the plaintiff was a prolific litigator and declared three-strikes litigant with a history of filing frivolous litigant and refusing to comply with court orders, and that in the present case had willfully refused to be deposed, among other similar tactics. On the same date, for the same reasons, the court found for the defendant.
case_data.summary_short: This case involves a prisoner at San Quentin State Prison who, on September 11, 2018, filed a pro se claim under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 in the Northern District of California, alleging that a correctional officer used excessive force by shooting him multiple times during an attack by other prisoners. The plaintiff sought injunctive, declaratory, and monetary relief, and the case was assigned to Judge Beth Labson Freeman. The complaint was amended multiple times following dismissals, and the court denied several motions by the plaintiff, including motions for appointment of counsel and a motion for judicial recusal. The court eventually dismissed the case in December 2020 for failure to exhaust administrative remedies and dismissed the supervisory liability claims. The plaintiff appealed, and on May 23, 2022, the Ninth Circuit reversed the dismissal for failure to exhaust administrative remedies and remanded the case. However, on June 17, 2024, the district court granted the defendantโs motion for terminating sanctions and ruled in the defendantโs favor.

1 MEMORANDUM OF POINTS AND AUTHORITIES
2 INTRODUCTION
3 After three attempts over the course of one year, Defendant Clawson still has been unable
4 to take the deposition of Plaintiff Shikeb Saddozai.  Despite multiple court orders and the courtโs
5 and counselโs warnings that he may be subject to sanctionsโincluding the dismissal of this
6 actionโPlaintiff initially refused to be sworn, and then insisted that he may be represented by
7 counsel, as well as other untruths, to prevent his deposition from proceeding.  And he has been
8 using the same tactics in his other pending litigation, including one case that was just dismissed
9 for Plaintiff repeated, willful refusal to be deposed.  Because Plaintiff is a prolific litigator and
10 declared three-strikes litigant, who is currently proceeding in forma pauperis, nothing short of
11 terminating sanctions will stop his continued waste of party and judicial resources.  This court
12 should dismiss the action with prejudice, and award Defendants costs and attorneysโ fees
13 reasonably incurred in their second and third attempts to take Plaintiffโs deposition.
14 BACKGROUND
15 Plaintiff is a prolific litigator and declared three-strikes litigant with a history of filing
16 frivolous litigant and refusing to comply with court orders.  (See ECF No. 75-2 at ยถยถ 18-20.)  In
17 this action, Plaintiff alleges that Defendant Clawson, a correctional officer at San Quentin State
18 Prison, utilized excessive force against Plaintiff when Defendant Clawson discharged a sponge
19 round at Plaintiffโs lower extremities, while Plaintiff was engaged in a fight with multiple
20 inmates.  (ECF No. 29 at 4.)  But Plaintiff has now thrice prevented Defendant Clawson from
21 asking Plaintiff questions about his allegations.
22 A. Plaintiff Refused to Be Deposed on November 17, 2022.
23 Defendant Clawson initially noticed Plaintiffโs deposition for November 17, 2022.  (ECF
24 No. 63-2 at 1-2.)  Between the date the deposition notice was served and the date of the
25 deposition, defense counsel did not receive any communication from Plaintiff, let alone any
26 objection to the taking of his deposition.  (Id. at 2.)  However, on November 17, 2022, Plaintiff
27 refused to be transported to the deposition location.  (Id. at 2-3.)  Plaintiff demanded various
28 accommodations before he would agree to be transported, but correctional staff reviewed
1
Not. Mot. & Renewed Mot. Terminating & Monetary Sanctions (5:18-cv-05558-BLF (PR))

Case 5:18-cv-05558-BLF     Document 91     Filed 10/18/23     Page 4 of 14
1 Plaintiffโs electronic prison file and determined that he was not entitled to any of the demanded
2 accommodations.  (Id.)  Because Plaintiff would not agree to be transported to the deposition
3 without those accommodations, the deposition could not proceed and was suspended.  (Id.)
4 Defendant Clawson incurred $1,108.25 in costs and fees associated with his attempt to
5 depose Plaintiff on November 17, 2022.  (Id. at 3.)
6 B. Plaintiff Was Ordered to Appear for and Submit to an Oral Deposition on
February 9, 2023, but Again Refused.
7
8 Defendant Clawson moved to compel Plaintiffโs deposition, and re-noticed Plaintiffโs
9 deposition for February 9, 2023 at 10:00 a.m.1  (ECF No. 63; ECF No. 75-2 at ยถ 3.)  Plaintiff
10 opposed the motion to compel, and in his opposition he requested the appointment of counsel.
11 (ECF No. 65.)  The court granted Defendantโs motion to compel, admonishing Plaintiff that
12 unless he โprefers the more severe sanction of dismissal of this entire action for his refusal to
13 appear for the deposition under Rule 37(b)(2)(A)(v) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, he
14 shall appear for and submit to an oral deposition on February 9, 2023 at 10:00 a.m. as he has been
15 noticed by Defendantโs counsel.โ  (ECF No. 67 at 4.)  In the same order, the court denied
16 Plaintiffโs request for appointment of counsel, noting the court had already denied multiple
17 requests by Plaintiff and explaining that โ[p]reparing for a deposition is not an exceptional
18 circumstance that warrants the appointment of counsel.โ  (Id.)
19 Therefore, on February 9, 2023, defense counsel appeared in person for Plaintiffโs
20 deposition.  (ECF No. 75-2 at ยถ 7.)  Plaintiff appeared, was swornโthough he objected to taking
21 the oathโand stated his name for the record.  (ECF No. 75-3, Exh. 4 at 5:1-25.)  But after that,
22 Plaintiff refused to answer questions.  (See id. at 6:1-16:7.)  Plaintiff objected that he risked
23 โwaiving an objection provided by the errors and irregularities occurring at the oral deposition โฆ
24 in the manner of taking the deposition in a form of questions and answers[,] in the oath or
25 affirmation[,] or in the conduct of the parties and errors of any kind[,] which might be obviated or
26 removed or cured if promptly presented or waived unless suitable objection thereto was made at
27 the taking of the deposition.โ  (Id. at 6:2-16.)  Plaintiff went on to object that he could not proceed
28 1 He also moved for monetary sanctions, which were denied.  (SeeECF Nos. 63, 67.)
2
Not. Mot. & Renewed Mot. Terminating & Monetary Sanctions (5:18-cv-05558-BLF (PR))

Case 5:18-cv-05558-BLF     Document 91     Filed 10/18/23     Page 5 of 14
1 because he โdid not have the assistance of counsel and absence,โ and could not โmake
2 uncounseled responses.โ  (Id.)  Plaintiff also objected that he was not prepared due to several
3 medical issues,โ but would identify the medical issues.  (Id. at 7:1-25.)
4 Defense counsel presented Plaintiff with a copy of the courtโs order granting Defendantโs
5 motion to compel, and Plaintiff acknowledged receiving the order and acknowledged that he
6 understood his deposition testimony had been compelled.  (Id. at 9:11-12:13.)  Defense counsel
7 read Plaintiff the portion of the order in which the court advised Plaintiff that if he did not appear
8 for and submit to an oral deposition, the action could be terminated, and later orally advised
9 Plaintiff that his failure to answer questions could result in monetary and/or terminating
10 sanctions.  (Id. at 9:11-16:7.)  But Plaintiff just repeated his objection about the risk of waiving
11 the โerrors and irregularitiesโ with the deposition if he proceeded without counsel, confirmed that
12 objection would be his response to every question posed, and reiterated that he would not answer
13 questions without the assistance of counsel.  (Id.)  The deposition was then suspended.  (Id.)
14 C. Defendant Moved for Terminating Sanctions, Which Were Denied, But
Plaintiff Was Afforded a Final Opportunity to Sit for and Participate in
15 His Deposition.
16 Defendant Clawson sought terminating and monetary sanctions for Plaintiffโs repeated
17 refusal to participate in his deposition.  (ECF No. 75.)  This Court found Defendantโs motion
18 โpersuasive,โ but โin the interest of justice and his pro se status,โ the Court denied the motion
19 without prejudice so that Plaintiff could be afforded โone final opportunity to comply and submit
20 to an oral deposition, which includes making a good faith effort to answer all questions posed by
21 Defendantโs counsel.โ  (ECF No. 88 at 5.)  Plaintiff was warned that โhis failure to appear and
22 answer questions in good faith will result in terminating sanctions and the award or reasonable
23 fees and costs to Defendantโs counsel.โ  (Id. at 5.)
24 Defendant Clawson noticed Plaintiffโs deposition for October 4, 2023, at 10:00 a.m.
25 (Shryock Decl., ยถ 5.)  Defendant Clawson served Plaintiff with notice of the deposition on
26 September 11, 2023, and simultaneously served Plaintiff with an additional copy of the courtโs
27 order (ECF No. 88), and offering to accommodate any medical needs Plaintiff had.  (Shryock
28
3
Not. Mot. & Renewed Mot. Terminating & Monetary Sanctions (5:18-cv-05558-BLF (PR))

Case 5:18-cv-05558-BLF     Document 91     Filed 10/18/23     Page 6 of 14
1 Decl., ยถ 5, Exhs. 1-2.)  Between September 11 and October 4, 2023, defense counsel did not
2 receive any communications from Plaintiff.  (Shryock Decl., ยถ 6.)
3 D. Plaintiff Prevented His Deposition from Proceeding on October 4, 2023.
4 On October 4, 2023, defense counsel again traveled to San Quentin State Prison to depose
5 Plaintiff.  (Shryock Decl., ยถ 7.)  However, Plaintiff initially refused to be sworn on various
6 grounds, including a religious objection, claiming not to understand the oath, and because he was
7 in the process of obtaining counsel.  (Shryock Decl., ยถ 8, Exh. 3 at 6:8-9:9.)  Plaintiff later was
8 sworn, but he objected to being placed under oath, claiming he was under โduressโ because of the
9 courtโs orders.  (Shryock Decl., Exh. 3 at 14:13-16:19.)  Plaintiff acknowledged receiving the
10 amended notice of deposition, as well as counselโs letter about requesting accommodations for
11 the deposition.  (Id. at 11:3-13:22.)  Plaintiff admitted he never responded to either.  (Id.)
12 Plaintiff maintainedโDefendant contends erroneouslyโthat he โmay beโ represented by
13 counsel because he had corresponded with multiple attorneys about taking his case.  (Id. at 9:10-
14 10:22, 13:11-22, 17:14-18:5.)  But Plaintiffโs most recent communication with an attorney about
15 potentially taking his case was a letter dated July 2023.  (Id.)  Based upon Plaintiffโs
16 representation that he โdid not knowโ whether he was represented by counsel and that he โmay
17 beโ represented, counsel did not believe she could proceed with the deposition, and therefore
18 suspended the deposition at that time.  (Shryock Decl., ยถ 11, Exh. 3 at 17:14-18:21.)
19 Defendant Clawson now renews his motion for terminating sanctions.
20 DISCUSSION
21 I. THECOURTSHOULDTERMINATETHISACTION WITHPREJUDICE FORPLAINTIFFโS
REPEATEDFAILURE TOCOOPERATE INDISCOVERY ANDCOMPLY WITHCOURT
22 ORDERS.
23 Plaintiffโs repeated, willful refusal to sit for and submit to deposition warrants terminating
24 sanctions.  District courts have the inherent power to control their dockets, and โin the exercise of
25 that power they may impose sanctions including dismissal of a case.โ Thompson v. Housing
26 Auth., 782 F.2d 829, 831 (9th Cir. 1986).  Under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 37(b)(2)(A)(v),
27 district courts are empowered to dismiss an action if a party fails to obey an order to provide or
28 permit discovery.  Similarly, Rule 41(b) expressly authorizes dismissals for failure to comply
4
Not. Mot. & Renewed Mot. Terminating & Monetary Sanctions (5:18-cv-05558-BLF (PR))

Case 5:18-cv-05558-BLF     Document 91     Filed 10/18/23     Page 7 of 14
1 with a court order.  The standards governing dismissals under these two rules are โbasically the
2 same.โ Malone v. U.S. Postal Serv., 833 F.2d 128, 130 (9th Cir. 1987) (reviewing dismissal
3 under Rules 37 and 41).
4 In determining if dismissal is the appropriate sanction, courts weigh five factors: (1) the
5 public interest in expeditious resolution of litigation; (2) the courtโs need to manage its docket; (3)
6 the risk of prejudice to the defendants; (4) the public policy favoring disposition of cases on their
7 merits; (5) the availability of less drastic sanctions. Pagtalunan v. Galaza, 291 F.3d 639, 641
8 (9th Cir. 1986).  Although it is preferred, it is not required that the district court make explicit
9 findings to show that it has considered these factors. Yourish v. Cal. Amplifier, 191 F.3d 983, 990
10 (9th Cir. 1999).  These factors are tools of analysis, not โconditions precedentโ to the district
11 courtโs imposition of sanctions. Allen v. Bayer Corp. (In re PPA), 460 F.3d 1217, 1226 (9th Cir.
12 2006).  Here, the factors weigh in favor of terminating sanctions.
13 A. The First and Second Factorsโthe Public Interest in Expeditious
Resolution and Management of the Courtโs DocketโWeigh in Favor of
14 Dismissal.
15 The first two factorsโexpeditious resolution and the Courtโs docket managementโalways
16 weigh in favor of dismissal. Malone, 833 F.2d at 130-31.  The public has โan overriding interestโ
17 in the orderly, expeditious, and inexpensive determination of every action. In re PPA, 460 F.3d at
18 1227.  Delay in reaching the merits is โcostly in money, memory, manageability, and confidence
19 in the process.โ Id. at 1227.  Although cases generally should be disposed of on their merits, a
20 plaintiff is responsible for moving his case toward that disposition. See Morris v. Morgan Stanley
21 & Co., 942 F.2d 648, 652 (9th Cir. 1991).  The power to invoke terminating sanctions โis
22 necessary in order to prevent undue delays in the disposition of pending cases and to avoid
23 congestion in the calendars of the district courts.โ Link v. Wabash R.R. Co., 371 U.S. 626, 629 โ
24 30 (1962).
25 Here, Plaintiffโs repeated and willful refusal to submit to depositionโin contravention of
26 two court ordersโis impeding the advancement of this case.  This action was filed on September
27 11, 2018.  (ECF No. 1.)  Yet, five years later, Defendant cannot determine whether a dispositive
28 motion is appropriate, or prepare one, until he has deposed Plaintiff.  And Plaintiff has prevented
5
Not. Mot. & Renewed Mot. Terminating & Monetary Sanctions (5:18-cv-05558-BLF (PR))

Case 5:18-cv-05558-BLF     Document 91     Filed 10/18/23     Page 8 of 14
1 him from doing that for almost one year.  (See ECF Nos. 62, 75.)  Plaintiffโs deposition was
2 initially noticed for November 2022, but Plaintiff refused to be transported to the deposition
3 location.  (See ECF No. 62.)  The court ordered Plaintiff to sit for deposition in February, and
4 extended Defendantsโ deadline to file a summary-judgment motion.  (See ECF No. 67 at 4.)  But
5 Plaintiff again refused to answer questions.  (ECF No. 75-3, Exh. 4.)  This Court then gave
6 Plaintiff โone, final opportunityโ to answer Defendant Clawsonโs questions, but Plaintiff againโ
7 for a third timeโimpeded Defendantโs ability to ask Plaintiff questions about this case.  (ECF
8 No. 88 at 5.)  Plaintiffโs refusal to sit for deposition has resulted in no less than three motions
9 being brought, and has extended discovery by one year.  Further, there is no indication that
10 Plaintiff intends to change his behavior.  He recently had another case dismissed for his repeated
11 refusal to sit for deposition (Shryock Decl., Exhs. 4-5), and yet in this and one other pending case
12 he continues to refuse to be deposed unless he is represented by counsel.  (Shryock Dec., ยถ 19,
13 Exh. 3.)
14 Plaintiffโs behavior impedes the Courtโs strong interest in docket control and expeditious
15 resolution of cases.  These factors weigh in favor of dismissal.
16 B. The Third FactorโPrejudice to DefendantsโAlso Weighs in Favor of
Dismissal.
17
18 Defendant Clawson has been and continues to be prejudiced by Plaintiffโs refusal to sit for
19 deposition and answer questions about his claim. See Adriana Intโl Corp. v. Thoeren, 913 F.2d
20 1406, 1412 (9th Cir. 1990).  Prejudice may take the form of loss of evidence, loss of memory, and
21 costs or burdens of litigation. In re PPA, 460 F.3d at 1338.  The law also presumes that an
22 unreasonable delay causes prejudice. Anderson v. Air West Inc., 542 F.2d 522, 524 (9th Cir.
23 1976).  Courts have interpreted Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 41(b) to require a plaintiff to
24 prosecute with โreasonable diligenceโ to avoid dismissal. Id.  The failure to prosecute diligently
25 is โsufficient by itself to justify dismissal, even in the absence of showing actual prejudice to the
26 defendant from the failure.โ Id.
27
28
6
Not. Mot. & Renewed Mot. Terminating & Monetary Sanctions (5:18-cv-05558-BLF (PR))

Case 5:18-cv-05558-BLF     Document 91     Filed 10/18/23     Page 9 of 14
1 First, Defendant is prejudiced because he cannot defend against Plaintiffโs claim because he
2 has not been able to ask Plaintiff about the facts that form the basis of that claim.  If Defendant
3 Clawson cannot ask questions about the allegations against him, he cannot properly evaluate the
4 claims against him or determine whether possible defenses are viable.  (ECF No. 75-2 at ยถ 17.)
5 Thus, at this time, Defendant Clawson cannot prepare a summary-judgment motionโor even
6 determine if such a motion is warrantedโor prepare a defense for trial.  (Id.)  Defendant Clawson
7 is also prejudiced by the cost of repeatedly preparing for and attempting to depose Plaintiff, and
8 bringing multiple discovery and extension motions before the court.  (See, e.g., ECF Nos. 63, 63-
9 2 at 3; 75-2.)  Defendant Clawson incurred no less than $1,108.25 for his attempt to depose
10 Plaintiff in November 2022, and he incurred an additional $1,952.05 and $2,015.56 in fees and
11 costs in connection with Plaintiffโs (failed) February 9 and October 4, 2023, depositions.  (ECF
12 No. 75-2 at ยถยถ 14-16; Shryock Decl., ยถยถ 13-15.)  And these costs are only a fraction of the costs
13 Defendant Clawson actually incurred.  (See id.)
14 Second, Plaintiffโs behavior has unreasonably delayed this action, and (after five years
15 since Plaintiffโs allegations occurred), this leads to evidence loss, witness loss, and memory loss,
16 all of which are prejudicial to Defendant Clawson.  And Plaintiffโs conduct is antithetical to his
17 duty to prosecute his case.  The third factor favors dismissal.
18 C. The Fourth FactorโPublic Policy Favoring a Merits DecisionโDoes Not
Favor Dismissal, But Also Does Not Preclude It.
19
20 The only factor that weighs against dismissal is the public policy favoring disposition on
21 the merits. In re PPA, 460 F.2d at 1228.  But โthis factor lends little support to a party whose
22 responsibility is to move the case toward disposition on the merits but whose conduct impedes
23 progress in that direction.โ Id. (internal quotations omitted).  Plaintiffโs error in โhalting
24 movement towards a merits solutionโ should โsubstantially neutralize[] the negative effect of this
25 factor.โ Id. at 1237.  And this factor is a weak factor that does not preclude dismissal where the
26 other factors weigh in favor of dismissal. Rio Properties, Inc. v. Rio Intโl Interlink, 284 F.2d
27 1007, 1022 (9th Cir. 2022).  Here, Plaintiff brought this case against Defendant Clawson, and
28 thus, he has the responsibility to diligently prosecute the case and move the case forward toward
7
Not. Mot. & Renewed Mot. Terminating & Monetary Sanctions (5:18-cv-05558-BLF (PR))

Case 5:18-cv-05558-BLF     Document 91     Filed 10/18/23     Page 10 of 14
1 its disposition. See Morris v. Morgan & Co., 942 F.2d at 652.  His failure to comply with the
2 Courtโs orders to appear for and submit to an oral deposition stalls the resolution of the case and
3 prevents Defendant Clawson from understanding the merits of Plaintiffโs claim.  Therefore,
4 Plaintiff cannot avail himself of this factor.
5 D. The Fifth FactorโWhether Alternative Sanctions Are Available, and
Whether Plaintiff Received a WarningโWeighs In Favor of Dismissal.
6
7 Evaluation of the last factorโthe availability of less drastic sanctionsโis satisfied through
8 the district courtโs โreasonable exploration of possible and meaningful alternatives.โ Morris, 942
9 F.2d at 652.  Warning a party that failure to obey a court order will result in dismissal can itself
10 meet the โconsideration of alternativesโ requirement. In re PPA, 460 F.3d at 1229.
11 Here, the Court has warned Plaintiff, twice, of the possible dismissal of this case through its
12 order compelling Plaintiffโs deposition.  (ECF No. 67, 75.)  In its order granting Defendantโs
13 motion to compel, this court stated: โ[u]nless Plaintiff prefers the more severe sanction of
14 dismissal of this entire action for his refusal to appear for the deposition under Rule
15 37(b)(2)(A)(v) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, he shall appear for and submit to an oral
16 deposition on February 9, 2023 at 10:00 a.m. as he has been noticed by Defendantโs counsel.โ
17 (ECF No. 67 at 4.)  Plaintiff acknowledged receiving this order before the deposition, and defense
18 counsel read the relevant portion of the order to Plaintiff on February 9, 2023.  (Pl.โs Depo at
19 9:11-16:7.)  Still, Plaintiff refused to answer questions.  (Id.)
20 Then, in its order denying Defendantโs motion for terminating sanctions without prejudice,
21 this Court admonished Plaintiff โthat his failure to appear and answer questions in good faith will
22 result in terminating sanctions and the award or reasonable fees and costs to Defendantโs
23 counsel.โ  (ECF No. 88 at 5.)  Defendant Clawson also served Plaintiff with an additional copy of
24 the order, and inquired about Plaintiffโs medical needs so that they could be accommodated
25 during his deposition.  (Shryock Decl., ยถยถ 5-6, Exhs. 1-2.)  While Plaintiff acknowledged
26 receiving both the Courtโs order and Defendantโs letter, he never responded, and he deliberately
27 prevented the deposition from going forward.  (See Shryock Decl., ยถ 9, Exh. 3.)  This is after
28
8
Not. Mot. & Renewed Mot. Terminating & Monetary Sanctions (5:18-cv-05558-BLF (PR))

Case 5:18-cv-05558-BLF     Document 91     Filed 10/18/23     Page 11 of 14
1 another one of his cases was dismissed for his repeated, willful refusal to sit for deposition.  (See
2 Shryock Decl., Exhs. 4-5.).
3 The threat of sanctions has not deterred Plaintiffโs behavior, nor did court orders gain his
4 compliance.  Even the imposition of terminating sanctions in another matter has not changed
5 Plaintiffโs behavior.  (See Shryock Decl., Exhs. 4-5.)  And monetary sanctions will not suffice.
6 Because Plaintiff is proceeding in forma pauperis (ECF No. 6), monetary sanctions are not a
7 viable alternative. See Jenkins v. Biter, 13-cv-02724 VBF (RZ), 2014 WL 11742143, *2 (C.D.
8 Cal. 2014) (concluding same and compiling cases reaching similar conclusion).  Further,
9 Defendant Clawson sought over $1,000 in sanctions for Plaintiffโs failure to appear for his initial
10 deposition, and the threat of facing similar sanctions for his refusal to answer questions at his
11 second deposition did not induce Plaintiff to cooperate.  (See Pl.โs Depo. at 15:6-16:7.)  Because
12 Plaintiff was not deterred by the threat of monetary sanctions, and has been warned of the
13 possibility of terminating sanctions if he continued to refuse to comply with this courtโs order on
14 multiple occasions, nothing short of terminating this action with prejudice will deter Plaintiff
15 from repeating his behavior.  The last factor, thus, weighs in favor of dismissal.
16 Because the balance of factors support termination, this action should be dismissed with
17 prejudice.
18 II. DEFENDANTCLAWSONISALSOENTITLED TOMONETARYSANCTIONS.
19 This court should also award Defendant Clawson attorneyโs fees and costs associated with
20 his three attempts to depose Plaintiff to punish Plaintiffโs bad-faith conduct and deter such
21 conduct in the future.
22 In addition to imposing sanctions for a partyโs failure to appear for their deposition, a โcourt
23 must require the party failing to act . . . to pay the reasonable expenses, including attorneyโs fees,
24 caused by the failure, unless the failure was substantially justified or other circumstances make an
25 award of expenses unjust.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 37(d)(3).  A failure to appear need not be willful, but
26 โwillfulnessโ plays a role in the choice of sanctions.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 37(d)(3), Advisory
27 Committee Notes, 1970 Amendment.  And when making a bad-faith determination, the court is
28 entitled to reply on the partyโs motivations and can consider the partyโs conduct in other cases.
9
Not. Mot. & Renewed Mot. Terminating & Monetary Sanctions (5:18-cv-05558-BLF (PR))

Case 5:18-cv-05558-BLF     Document 91     Filed 10/18/23     Page 12 of 14
1 See Halaco v. Engโg Co. v. Costle, 843 F.2d 376, 381 n.2 (9th Cir. 1988) (โcourt may indeed
2 consider prior conduct that has already been subject to sanction, when it is weighing a subsequent
3 sanction motionโ); see also Smith v. Smith, 145 F.3d 335, 344 (5th Cir. 1998).
4 Here, Defendant Clawson requests the court award him his costs and attorneyโs feesโor
5 some portion thereofโassociated with his second and third attempts to depose Plaintiff because
6 Plaintiffโs conduct was not substantially justified, and other circumstances do not make such an
7 award unjust. See Fed. R. Civ. P. 37(d)(3).  Plaintiff repeatedly refused to answer questions,
8 despite being advised by the court and counsel that โ[t]he failure of Plaintiff to attend, be sworn,
9 or answer appropriate questions may result in sanctions, including dismissal of the action
10 pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 37.โ  And this is not the first time Plaintiff has wasted court or party
11 resources.  Plaintiff is a declared three-strikes litigant who has previously had at least one case
12 dismissed for failure to comply with court orders and multiple appeals certified as frivolous.
13 (ECF No. 75-2 at ยถยถ 18-20.)  If his obstructionist behavior is permitted to continue, he will only
14 continue to waste the time of defendants and the courts in other cases.
15 Defendant Clawson incurred $1,127.05 in costs, and $825 in attorneysโ fees, for a total of
16 $1,952.05, in connection with his attempt to depose Plaintiff on February 9, 2023.  (ECF No. 75-2
17 at ยถยถ 14-16.)  And Defendant Clawson incurred an additional $1,245.56 in costs, and $770 in
18 attorneysโ fees, for a total of $2,015.56, in connection with his attempt to depose Plaintiff on
19 October 4, 2023.  (Shryock Decl., ยถยถ 14-16.)  Because Plaintiffโs refusal to answer questions was
20 not in good faith, Defendant Clawson is entitled to his costs and fees, for a total of $3,967.61, or
21 some portion thereof.
22

1 CONCLUSION
2 Nothing short of termination will deter Plaintiffโs repeated, bad-faith behavior.  The court
3 should dismiss this action with prejudice and award Defendants $3,967.61 in costs and fees.

1 MEMORANDUM OF POINTS AND AUTHORITIES
2 INTRODUCTION
3 After three attempts over the course of one year, Defendant Clawson still has been unable
4 to take the deposition of Plaintiff Shikeb Saddozai.  Despite multiple court orders and the courtโs
5 and counselโs warnings that he may be subject to sanctionsโincluding the dismissal of this
6 actionโPlaintiff initially refused to be sworn, and then insisted that he may be represented by
7 counsel, as well as other untruths, to prevent his deposition from proceeding.  And he has been
8 using the same tactics in his other pending litigation, including one case that was just dismissed
9 for Plaintiff repeated, willful refusal to be deposed.  Because Plaintiff is a prolific litigator and
10 declared three-strikes litigant, who is currently proceeding in forma pauperis, nothing short of
11 terminating sanctions will stop his continued waste of party and judicial resources.  This court
12 should dismiss the action with prejudice, and award Defendants costs and attorneysโ fees
13 reasonably incurred in their second and third attempts to take Plaintiffโs deposition.
14 BACKGROUND
15 Plaintiff is a prolific litigator and declared three-strikes litigant with a history of filing
16 frivolous litigant and refusing to comply with court orders.  (See ECF No. 75-2 at ยถยถ 18-20.)  In
17 this action, Plaintiff alleges that Defendant Clawson, a correctional officer at San Quentin State
18 Prison, utilized excessive force against Plaintiff when Defendant Clawson discharged a sponge
19 round at Plaintiffโs lower extremities, while Plaintiff was engaged in a fight with multiple
20 inmates.  (ECF No. 29 at 4.)  But Plaintiff has now thrice prevented Defendant Clawson from
21 asking Plaintiff questions about his allegations.
22 A. Plaintiff Refused to Be Deposed on November 17, 2022.
23 Defendant Clawson initially noticed Plaintiffโs deposition for November 17, 2022.  (ECF
24 No. 63-2 at 1-2.)  Between the date the deposition notice was served and the date of the
25 deposition, defense counsel did not receive any communication from Plaintiff, let alone any
26 objection to the taking of his deposition.  (Id. at 2.)  However, on November 17, 2022, Plaintiff
27 refused to be transported to the deposition location.  (Id. at 2-3.)  Plaintiff demanded various
28 accommodations before he would agree to be transported, but correctional staff reviewed
1
Not. Mot. & Renewed Mot. Terminating & Monetary Sanctions (5:18-cv-05558-BLF (PR))

Case 5:18-cv-05558-BLF     Document 91     Filed 10/18/23     Page 4 of 14
1 Plaintiffโs electronic prison file and determined that he was not entitled to any of the demanded
2 accommodations.  (Id.)  Because Plaintiff would not agree to be transported to the deposition
3 without those accommodations, the deposition could not proceed and was suspended.  (Id.)
4 Defendant Clawson incurred $1,108.25 in costs and fees associated with his attempt to
5 depose Plaintiff on November 17, 2022.  (Id. at 3.)
6 B. Plaintiff Was Ordered to Appear for and Submit to an Oral Deposition on
February 9, 2023, but Again Refused.
7
8 Defendant Clawson moved to compel Plaintiffโs deposition, and re-noticed Plaintiffโs
9 deposition for February 9, 2023 at 10:00 a.m.1  (ECF No. 63; ECF No. 75-2 at ยถ 3.)  Plaintiff
10 opposed the motion to compel, and in his opposition he requested the appointment of counsel.
11 (ECF No. 65.)  The court granted Defendantโs motion to compel, admonishing Plaintiff that
12 unless he โprefers the more severe sanction of dismissal of this entire action for his refusal to
13 appear for the deposition under Rule 37(b)(2)(A)(v) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, he
14 shall appear for and submit to an oral deposition on February 9, 2023 at 10:00 a.m. as he has been
15 noticed by Defendantโs counsel.โ  (ECF No. 67 at 4.)  In the same order, the court denied
16 Plaintiffโs request for appointment of counsel, noting the court had already denied multiple
17 requests by Plaintiff and explaining that โ[p]reparing for a deposition is not an exceptional
18 circumstance that warrants the appointment of counsel.โ  (Id.)
19 Therefore, on February 9, 2023, defense counsel appeared in person for Plaintiffโs
20 deposition.  (ECF No. 75-2 at ยถ 7.)  Plaintiff appeared, was swornโthough he objected to taking
21 the oathโand stated his name for the record.  (ECF No. 75-3, Exh. 4 at 5:1-25.)  But after that,
22 Plaintiff refused to answer questions.  (See id. at 6:1-16:7.)  Plaintiff objected that he risked
23 โwaiving an objection provided by the errors and irregularities occurring at the oral deposition โฆ
24 in the manner of taking the deposition in a form of questions and answers[,] in the oath or
25 affirmation[,] or in the conduct of the parties and errors of any kind[,] which might be obviated or
26 removed or cured if promptly presented or waived unless suitable objection thereto was made at
27 the taking of the deposition.โ  (Id. at 6:2-16.)  Plaintiff went on to object that he could not proceed
28 1 He also moved for monetary sanctions, which were denied.  (SeeECF Nos. 63, 67.)
2
Not. Mot. & Renewed Mot. Terminating & Monetary Sanctions (5:18-cv-05558-BLF (PR))

Case 5:18-cv-05558-BLF     Document 91     Filed 10/18/23     Page 5 of 14
1 because he โdid not have the assistance of counsel and absence,โ and could not โmake
2 uncounseled responses.โ  (Id.)  Plaintiff also objected that he was not prepared due to several
3 medical issues,โ but would identify the medical issues.  (Id. at 7:1-25.)
4 Defense counsel presented Plaintiff with a copy of the courtโs order granting Defendantโs
5 motion to compel, and Plaintiff acknowledged receiving the order and acknowledged that he
6 understood his deposition testimony had been compelled.  (Id. at 9:11-12:13.)  Defense counsel
7 read Plaintiff the portion of the order in which the court advised Plaintiff that if he did not appear
8 for and submit to an oral deposition, the action could be terminated, and later orally advised
9 Plaintiff that his failure to answer questions could result in monetary and/or terminating
10 sanctions.  (Id. at 9:11-16:7.)  But Plaintiff just repeated his objection about the risk of waiving
11 the โerrors and irregularitiesโ with the deposition if he proceeded without counsel, confirmed that
12 objection would be his response to every question posed, and reiterated that he would not answer
13 questions without the assistance of counsel.  (Id.)  The deposition was then suspended.  (Id.)
14 C. Defendant Moved for Terminating Sanctions, Which Were Denied, But
Plaintiff Was Afforded a Final Opportunity to Sit for and Participate in
15 His Deposition.
16 Defendant Clawson sought terminating and monetary sanctions for Plaintiffโs repeated
17 refusal to participate in his deposition.  (ECF No. 75.)  This Court found Defendantโs motion
18 โpersuasive,โ but โin the interest of justice and his pro se status,โ the Court denied the motion
19 without prejudice so that Plaintiff could be afforded โone final opportunity to comply and submit
20 to an oral deposition, which includes making a good faith effort to answer all questions posed by
21 Defendantโs counsel.โ  (ECF No. 88 at 5.)  Plaintiff was warned that โhis failure to appear and
22 answer questions in good faith will result in terminating sanctions and the award or reasonable
23 fees and costs to Defendantโs counsel.โ  (Id. at 5.)
24 Defendant Clawson noticed Plaintiffโs deposition for October 4, 2023, at 10:00 a.m.
25 (Shryock Decl., ยถ 5.)  Defendant Clawson served Plaintiff with notice of the deposition on
26 September 11, 2023, and simultaneously served Plaintiff with an additional copy of the courtโs
27 order (ECF No. 88), and offering to accommodate any medical needs Plaintiff had.  (Shryock
28
3
Not. Mot. & Renewed Mot. Terminating & Monetary Sanctions (5:18-cv-05558-BLF (PR))

Case 5:18-cv-05558-BLF     Document 91     Filed 10/18/23     Page 6 of 14
1 Decl., ยถ 5, Exhs. 1-2.)  Between September 11 and October 4, 2023, defense counsel did not
2 receive any communications from Plaintiff.  (Shryock Decl., ยถ 6.)
3 D. Plaintiff Prevented His Deposition from Proceeding on October 4, 2023.
4 On October 4, 2023, defense counsel again traveled to San Quentin State Prison to depose
5 Plaintiff.  (Shryock Decl., ยถ 7.)  However, Plaintiff initially refused to be sworn on various
6 grounds, including a religious objection, claiming not to understand the oath, and because he was
7 in the process of obtaining counsel.  (Shryock Decl., ยถ 8, Exh. 3 at 6:8-9:9.)  Plaintiff later was
8 sworn, but he objected to being placed under oath, claiming he was under โduressโ because of the
9 courtโs orders.  (Shryock Decl., Exh. 3 at 14:13-16:19.)  Plaintiff acknowledged receiving the
10 amended notice of deposition, as well as counselโs letter about requesting accommodations for
11 the deposition.  (Id. at 11:3-13:22.)  Plaintiff admitted he never responded to either.  (Id.)
12 Plaintiff maintainedโDefendant contends erroneouslyโthat he โmay beโ represented by
13 counsel because he had corresponded with multiple attorneys about taking his case.  (Id. at 9:10-
14 10:22, 13:11-22, 17:14-18:5.)  But Plaintiffโs most recent communication with an attorney about
15 potentially taking his case was a letter dated July 2023.  (Id.)  Based upon Plaintiffโs
16 representation that he โdid not knowโ whether he was represented by counsel and that he โmay
17 beโ represented, counsel did not believe she could proceed with the deposition, and therefore
18 suspended the deposition at that time.  (Shryock Decl., ยถ 11, Exh. 3 at 17:14-18:21.)
19 Defendant Clawson now renews his motion for terminating sanctions.
20 DISCUSSION
21 I. THECOURTSHOULDTERMINATETHISACTION WITHPREJUDICE FORPLAINTIFFโS
REPEATEDFAILURE TOCOOPERATE INDISCOVERY ANDCOMPLY WITHCOURT
22 ORDERS.
23 Plaintiffโs repeated, willful refusal to sit for and submit to deposition warrants terminating
24 sanctions.  District courts have the inherent power to control their dockets, and โin the exercise of
25 that power they may impose sanctions including dismissal of a case.โ Thompson v. Housing
26 Auth., 782 F.2d 829, 831 (9th Cir. 1986).  Under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 37(b)(2)(A)(v),
27 district courts are empowered to dismiss an action if a party fails to obey an order to provide or
28 permit discovery.  Similarly, Rule 41(b) expressly authorizes dismissals for failure to comply
4
Not. Mot. & Renewed Mot. Terminating & Monetary Sanctions (5:18-cv-05558-BLF (PR))

Case 5:18-cv-05558-BLF     Document 91     Filed 10/18/23     Page 7 of 14
1 with a court order.  The standards governing dismissals under these two rules are โbasically the
2 same.โ Malone v. U.S. Postal Serv., 833 F.2d 128, 130 (9th Cir. 1987) (reviewing dismissal
3 under Rules 37 and 41).
4 In determining if dismissal is the appropriate sanction, courts weigh five factors: (1) the
5 public interest in expeditious resolution of litigation; (2) the courtโs need to manage its docket; (3)
6 the risk of prejudice to the defendants; (4) the public policy favoring disposition of cases on their
7 merits; (5) the availability of less drastic sanctions. Pagtalunan v. Galaza, 291 F.3d 639, 641
8 (9th Cir. 1986).  Although it is preferred, it is not required that the district court make explicit
9 findings to show that it has considered these factors. Yourish v. Cal. Amplifier, 191 F.3d 983, 990
10 (9th Cir. 1999).  These factors are tools of analysis, not โconditions precedentโ to the district
11 courtโs imposition of sanctions. Allen v. Bayer Corp. (In re PPA), 460 F.3d 1217, 1226 (9th Cir.
12 2006).  Here, the factors weigh in favor of terminating sanctions.
13 A. The First and Second Factorsโthe Public Interest in Expeditious
Resolution and Management of the Courtโs DocketโWeigh in Favor of
14 Dismissal.
15 The first two factorsโexpeditious resolution and the Courtโs docket managementโalways
16 weigh in favor of dismissal. Malone, 833 F.2d at 130-31.  The public has โan overriding interestโ
17 in the orderly, expeditious, and inexpensive determination of every action. In re PPA, 460 F.3d at
18 1227.  Delay in reaching the merits is โcostly in money, memory, manageability, and confidence
19 in the process.โ Id. at 1227.  Although cases generally should be disposed of on their merits, a
20 plaintiff is responsible for moving his case toward that disposition. See Morris v. Morgan Stanley
21 & Co., 942 F.2d 648, 652 (9th Cir. 1991).  The power to invoke terminating sanctions โis
22 necessary in order to prevent undue delays in the disposition of pending cases and to avoid
23 congestion in the calendars of the district courts.โ Link v. Wabash R.R. Co., 371 U.S. 626, 629 โ
24 30 (1962).
25 Here, Plaintiffโs repeated and willful refusal to submit to depositionโin contravention of
26 two court ordersโis impeding the advancement of this case.  This action was filed on September
27 11, 2018.  (ECF No. 1.)  Yet, five years later, Defendant cannot determine whether a dispositive
28 motion is appropriate, or prepare one, until he has deposed Plaintiff.  And Plaintiff has prevented
5
Not. Mot. & Renewed Mot. Terminating & Monetary Sanctions (5:18-cv-05558-BLF (PR))

Case 5:18-cv-05558-BLF     Document 91     Filed 10/18/23     Page 8 of 14
1 him from doing that for almost one year.  (See ECF Nos. 62, 75.)  Plaintiffโs deposition was
2 initially noticed for November 2022, but Plaintiff refused to be transported to the deposition
3 location.  (See ECF No. 62.)  The court ordered Plaintiff to sit for deposition in February, and
4 extended Defendantsโ deadline to file a summary-judgment motion.  (See ECF No. 67 at 4.)  But
5 Plaintiff again refused to answer questions.  (ECF No. 75-3, Exh. 4.)  This Court then gave
6 Plaintiff โone, final opportunityโ to answer Defendant Clawsonโs questions, but Plaintiff againโ
7 for a third timeโimpeded Defendantโs ability to ask Plaintiff questions about this case.  (ECF
8 No. 88 at 5.)  Plaintiffโs refusal to sit for deposition has resulted in no less than three motions
9 being brought, and has extended discovery by one year.  Further, there is no indication that
10 Plaintiff intends to change his behavior.  He recently had another case dismissed for his repeated
11 refusal to sit for deposition (Shryock Decl., Exhs. 4-5), and yet in this and one other pending case
12 he continues to refuse to be deposed unless he is represented by counsel.  (Shryock Dec., ยถ 19,
13 Exh. 3.)
14 Plaintiffโs behavior impedes the Courtโs strong interest in docket control and expeditious
15 resolution of cases.  These factors weigh in favor of dismissal.
16 B. The Third FactorโPrejudice to DefendantsโAlso Weighs in Favor of
Dismissal.
17
18 Defendant Clawson has been and continues to be prejudiced by Plaintiffโs refusal to sit for
19 deposition and answer questions about his claim. See Adriana Intโl Corp. v. Thoeren, 913 F.2d
20 1406, 1412 (9th Cir. 1990).  Prejudice may take the form of loss of evidence, loss of memory, and
21 costs or burdens of litigation. In re PPA, 460 F.3d at 1338.  The law also presumes that an
22 unreasonable delay causes prejudice. Anderson v. Air West Inc., 542 F.2d 522, 524 (9th Cir.
23 1976).  Courts have interpreted Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 41(b) to require a plaintiff to
24 prosecute with โreasonable diligenceโ to avoid dismissal. Id.  The failure to prosecute diligently
25 is โsufficient by itself to justify dismissal, even in the absence of showing actual prejudice to the
26 defendant from the failure.โ Id.
27
28
6
Not. Mot. & Renewed Mot. Terminating & Monetary Sanctions (5:18-cv-05558-BLF (PR))

Case 5:18-cv-05558-BLF     Document 91     Filed 10/18/23     Page 9 of 14
1 First, Defendant is prejudiced because he cannot defend against Plaintiffโs claim because he
2 has not been able to ask Plaintiff about the facts that form the basis of that claim.  If Defendant
3 Clawson cannot ask questions about the allegations against him, he cannot properly evaluate the
4 claims against him or determine whether possible defenses are viable.  (ECF No. 75-2 at ยถ 17.)
5 Thus, at this time, Defendant Clawson cannot prepare a summary-judgment motionโor even
6 determine if such a motion is warrantedโor prepare a defense for trial.  (Id.)  Defendant Clawson
7 is also prejudiced by the cost of repeatedly preparing for and attempting to depose Plaintiff, and
8 bringing multiple discovery and extension motions before the court.  (See, e.g., ECF Nos. 63, 63-
9 2 at 3; 75-2.)  Defendant Clawson incurred no less than $1,108.25 for his attempt to depose
10 Plaintiff in November 2022, and he incurred an additional $1,952.05 and $2,015.56 in fees and
11 costs in connection with Plaintiffโs (failed) February 9 and October 4, 2023, depositions.  (ECF
12 No. 75-2 at ยถยถ 14-16; Shryock Decl., ยถยถ 13-15.)  And these costs are only a fraction of the costs
13 Defendant Clawson actually incurred.  (See id.)
14 Second, Plaintiffโs behavior has unreasonably delayed this action, and (after five years
15 since Plaintiffโs allegations occurred), this leads to evidence loss, witness loss, and memory loss,
16 all of which are prejudicial to Defendant Clawson.  And Plaintiffโs conduct is antithetical to his
17 duty to prosecute his case.  The third factor favors dismissal.
18 C. The Fourth FactorโPublic Policy Favoring a Merits DecisionโDoes Not
Favor Dismissal, But Also Does Not Preclude It.
19
20 The only factor that weighs against dismissal is the public policy favoring disposition on
21 the merits. In re PPA, 460 F.2d at 1228.  But โthis factor lends little support to a party whose
22 responsibility is to move the case toward disposition on the merits but whose conduct impedes
23 progress in that direction.โ Id. (internal quotations omitted).  Plaintiffโs error in โhalting
24 movement towards a merits solutionโ should โsubstantially neutralize[] the negative effect of this
25 factor.โ Id. at 1237.  And this factor is a weak factor that does not preclude dismissal where the
26 other factors weigh in favor of dismissal. Rio Properties, Inc. v. Rio Intโl Interlink, 284 F.2d
27 1007, 1022 (9th Cir. 2022).  Here, Plaintiff brought this case against Defendant Clawson, and
28 thus, he has the responsibility to diligently prosecute the case and move the case forward toward
7
Not. Mot. & Renewed Mot. Terminating & Monetary Sanctions (5:18-cv-05558-BLF (PR))

Case 5:18-cv-05558-BLF     Document 91     Filed 10/18/23     Page 10 of 14
1 its disposition. See Morris v. Morgan & Co., 942 F.2d at 652.  His failure to comply with the
2 Courtโs orders to appear for and submit to an oral deposition stalls the resolution of the case and
3 prevents Defendant Clawson from understanding the merits of Plaintiffโs claim.  Therefore,
4 Plaintiff cannot avail himself of this factor.
5 D. The Fifth FactorโWhether Alternative Sanctions Are Available, and
Whether Plaintiff Received a WarningโWeighs In Favor of Dismissal.
6
7 Evaluation of the last factorโthe availability of less drastic sanctionsโis satisfied through
8 the district courtโs โreasonable exploration of possible and meaningful alternatives.โ Morris, 942
9 F.2d at 652.  Warning a party that failure to obey a court order will result in dismissal can itself
10 meet the โconsideration of alternativesโ requirement. In re PPA, 460 F.3d at 1229.
11 Here, the Court has warned Plaintiff, twice, of the possible dismissal of this case through its
12 order compelling Plaintiffโs deposition.  (ECF No. 67, 75.)  In its order granting Defendantโs
13 motion to compel, this court stated: โ[u]nless Plaintiff prefers the more severe sanction of
14 dismissal of this entire action for his refusal to appear for the deposition under Rule
15 37(b)(2)(A)(v) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, he shall appear for and submit to an oral
16 deposition on February 9, 2023 at 10:00 a.m. as he has been noticed by Defendantโs counsel.โ
17 (ECF No. 67 at 4.)  Plaintiff acknowledged receiving this order before the deposition, and defense
18 counsel read the relevant portion of the order to Plaintiff on February 9, 2023.  (Pl.โs Depo at
19 9:11-16:7.)  Still, Plaintiff refused to answer questions.  (Id.)
20 Then, in its order denying Defendantโs motion for terminating sanctions without prejudice,
21 this Court admonished Plaintiff โthat his failure to appear and answer questions in good faith will
22 result in terminating sanctions and the award or reasonable fees and costs to Defendantโs
23 counsel.โ  (ECF No. 88 at 5.)  Defendant Clawson also served Plaintiff with an additional copy of
24 the order, and inquired about Plaintiffโs medical needs so that they could be accommodated
25 during his deposition.  (Shryock Decl., ยถยถ 5-6, Exhs. 1-2.)  While Plaintiff acknowledged
26 receiving both the Courtโs order and Defendantโs letter, he never responded, and he deliberately
27 prevented the deposition from going forward.  (See Shryock Decl., ยถ 9, Exh. 3.)  This is after
28
8
Not. Mot. & Renewed Mot. Terminating & Monetary Sanctions (5:18-cv-05558-BLF (PR))

Case 5:18-cv-05558-BLF     Document 91     Filed 10/18/23     Page 11 of 14
1 another one of his cases was dismissed for his repeated, willful refusal to sit for deposition.  (See
2 Shryock Decl., Exhs. 4-5.).
3 The threat of sanctions has not deterred Plaintiffโs behavior, nor did court orders gain his
4 compliance.  Even the imposition of terminating sanctions in another matter has not changed
5 Plaintiffโs behavior.  (See Shryock Decl., Exhs. 4-5.)  And monetary sanctions will not suffice.
6 Because Plaintiff is proceeding in forma pauperis (ECF No. 6), monetary sanctions are not a
7 viable alternative. See Jenkins v. Biter, 13-cv-02724 VBF (RZ), 2014 WL 11742143, *2 (C.D.
8 Cal. 2014) (concluding same and compiling cases reaching similar conclusion).  Further,
9 Defendant Clawson sought over $1,000 in sanctions for Plaintiffโs failure to appear for his initial
10 deposition, and the threat of facing similar sanctions for his refusal to answer questions at his
11 second deposition did not induce Plaintiff to cooperate.  (See Pl.โs Depo. at 15:6-16:7.)  Because
12 Plaintiff was not deterred by the threat of monetary sanctions, and has been warned of the
13 possibility of terminating sanctions if he continued to refuse to comply with this courtโs order on
14 multiple occasions, nothing short of terminating this action with prejudice will deter Plaintiff
15 from repeating his behavior.  The last factor, thus, weighs in favor of dismissal.
16 Because the balance of factors support termination, this action should be dismissed with
17 prejudice.
18 II. DEFENDANTCLAWSONISALSOENTITLED TOMONETARYSANCTIONS.
19 This court should also award Defendant Clawson attorneyโs fees and costs associated with
20 his three attempts to depose Plaintiff to punish Plaintiffโs bad-faith conduct and deter such
21 conduct in the future.
22 In addition to imposing sanctions for a partyโs failure to appear for their deposition, a โcourt
23 must require the party failing to act . . . to pay the reasonable expenses, including attorneyโs fees,
24 caused by the failure, unless the failure was substantially justified or other circumstances make an
25 award of expenses unjust.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 37(d)(3).  A failure to appear need not be willful, but
26 โwillfulnessโ plays a role in the choice of sanctions.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 37(d)(3), Advisory
27 Committee Notes, 1970 Amendment.  And when making a bad-faith determination, the court is
28 entitled to reply on the partyโs motivations and can consider the partyโs conduct in other cases.
9
Not. Mot. & Renewed Mot. Terminating & Monetary Sanctions (5:18-cv-05558-BLF (PR))

Case 5:18-cv-05558-BLF     Document 91     Filed 10/18/23     Page 12 of 14
1 See Halaco v. Engโg Co. v. Costle, 843 F.2d 376, 381 n.2 (9th Cir. 1988) (โcourt may indeed
2 consider prior conduct that has already been subject to sanction, when it is weighing a subsequent
3 sanction motionโ); see also Smith v. Smith, 145 F.3d 335, 344 (5th Cir. 1998).
4 Here, Defendant Clawson requests the court award him his costs and attorneyโs feesโor
5 some portion thereofโassociated with his second and third attempts to depose Plaintiff because
6 Plaintiffโs conduct was not substantially justified, and other circumstances do not make such an
7 award unjust. See Fed. R. Civ. P. 37(d)(3).  Plaintiff repeatedly refused to answer questions,
8 despite being advised by the court and counsel that โ[t]he failure of Plaintiff to attend, be sworn,
9 or answer appropriate questions may result in sanctions, including dismissal of the action
10 pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 37.โ  And this is not the first time Plaintiff has wasted court or party
11 resources.  Plaintiff is a declared three-strikes litigant who has previously had at least one case
12 dismissed for failure to comply with court orders and multiple appeals certified as frivolous.
13 (ECF No. 75-2 at ยถยถ 18-20.)  If his obstructionist behavior is permitted to continue, he will only
14 continue to waste the time of defendants and the courts in other cases.
15 Defendant Clawson incurred $1,127.05 in costs, and $825 in attorneysโ fees, for a total of
16 $1,952.05, in connection with his attempt to depose Plaintiff on February 9, 2023.  (ECF No. 75-2
17 at ยถยถ 14-16.)  And Defendant Clawson incurred an additional $1,245.56 in costs, and $770 in
18 attorneysโ fees, for a total of $2,015.56, in connection with his attempt to depose Plaintiff on
19 October 4, 2023.  (Shryock Decl., ยถยถ 14-16.)  Because Plaintiffโs refusal to answer questions was
20 not in good faith, Defendant Clawson is entitled to his costs and fees, for a total of $3,967.61, or
21 some portion thereof.

21  DISCUSSION 
22  A.  Standard of Review 
23    A federal court must conduct a preliminary screening in any case in which a 
24  prisoner seeks redress from a governmental entity or officer or employee of a 
25  governmental entity.  See 28 U.S.C. ยง 1915A(a).  In its review, the court must identify any 
26  cognizable claims and dismiss any claims that are frivolous, malicious, fail to state a claim

2    To state a claim under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983, a plaintiff must allege two essential 
3  elements: (1) that a right secured by the Constitution or laws of the United States was 
4  violated, and (2) that the alleged violation was committed by a person acting under the 
5  color of state law.  See West v. Atkins, 487 U.S. 42, 48 (1988). 
6  B.  Plaintiffโs Claims  
7  Plaintiff alleges several claims against different individuals at SQSP based on 
8  separate incidents that occurred on different dates during July, August and September 
9  2018.  (Compl. at 3-11.)  For example, he claims that on or about August 2, 2018, 
10  Defendant Officer Malikian threatened him in retaliation for filing inmate appeals.  (Id. at 
11  5.)  Plaintiff also claims that his request for various religious accommodations on July 31, 
12  2018, has gone unanswered, and that he has been experiencing ongoing restrictions in

19  โA party asserting a claim, counterclaim, crossclaim, or third-party claim may join, 
20  as independent or alternative claims, as many claims as it has against an opposing party.โ  
21  Fed. R. Civ. P. 18(a).  Accordingly, โmultiple claims against a single party are fine, but 
22  Claim A against Defendant 1 should not be joined with unrelated Claim B against 
23  Defendant 2.โ  George v. Smith, 507 F.3d 605, 607 (7th Cir. 2007).  โUnrelated claims 
24  against different defendants belong in different suits,โ not only to prevent the sort of 
25  โmorassโ that a multi-claim, multi-defendant suit can produce, โbut also to ensure that 
26  prisoners pay the required filing fees โ for the Prison Litigation Reform Act limits to 3 the 
27  number of frivolous suits or appeals that any prisoner may file without prepayment of 
28  2 

 
 
1  required fees.โ  Id. (citing 28 U.S.C. ยง 1915(g)).   
2  Here, it is clear the various claims raised against different defendants at SQSP are 
3  not all related to each other and do not all arise out of the same transaction, occurrence, or 
4  series of transactions or occurrences.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 20(a)(2).  โA buckshot complaint that 
5  would be rejected if filed by a free person โ say, a suit complaining that A defrauded 
6  plaintiff, B defamed him, C punched him, D failed to pay a debt, and E infringed his 
7  copyright, all in different transactions โ should be rejected if filed by a prisoner.โ  George 
8  v. Smith, 507 F.3d 605, 607 (7th Cir. 2007) (noting that, in prisoner complaint seeking to 
9  join 24 defendants and approximately 50 distinct claims, prisoner made no effort to show

4  is without prejudice to the Courtโs sua sponte appointment of counsel at a future date

19  U.S.C. ยง 1983.  Plaintiffโs motion for leave to proceed in forma pauperis will be addressed

22  A.  Standard of Review 
23    A federal court must conduct a preliminary screening in any case in which a 
24  prisoner seeks redress from a governmental entity or officer or employee of a 
25  governmental entity.  See 28 U.S.C. ยง 1915A(a).  In its review, the court must identify any 
26  cognizable claims and dismiss any claims that are frivolous, malicious, fail to state a claim 
27  upon which relief may be granted or seek monetary relief from a defendant who is immune 
28  from such relief.  See id. ยง 1915A(b)(1),(2).  Pro se pleadings must, however, be liberally 

 
 
1  construed.  See Balistreri v. Pacifica Police Depโt, 901 F.2d 696, 699 (9th Cir. 1988).   
2    To state a claim under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983, a plaintiff must allege two essential 
3  elements: (1) that a right secured by the Constitution or laws of the United States was 
4  violated, and (2) that the alleged violation was committed by a person acting under the 
5  color of state law.  See West v. Atkins, 487 U.S. 42, 48 (1988). 
6  B.  Plaintiffโs Claims  
7  Plaintiff alleges several claims against different individuals at SQSP based on 
8  separate incidents that occurred on different dates during July, August and September 
9  2018.  (Compl. at 3-11.)  For example, he claims that on or about August 2, 2018, 
10  Defendant Officer Malikian threatened him in retaliation for filing inmate appeals.  (Id. at

ct Cal 14  was attacked by inmates, and thereafter received inadequate medical treatment for his

tatDis 16  incident the failure to treat.  (Id. at 7-8.)  Plaintiff also claims denial of access to the prison

UNo 18  30, 2018, (id. at 11).   
19  โA party asserting a claim, counterclaim, crossclaim, or third-party claim may join, 
20  as independent or alternative claims, as many claims as it has against an opposing party.โ  
21  Fed. R. Civ. P. 18(a).  Accordingly, โmultiple claims against a single party are fine, but 
22  Claim A against Defendant 1 should not be joined with unrelated Claim B against 
23  Defendant 2.โ  George v. Smith, 507 F.3d 605, 607 (7th Cir. 2007).  โUnrelated claims 
24  against different defendants belong in different suits,โ not only to prevent the sort of 
25  โmorassโ that a multi-claim, multi-defendant suit can produce, โbut also to ensure that 
26  prisoners pay the required filing fees โ for the Prison Litigation Reform Act limits to 3 the 
27  number of frivolous suits or appeals that any prisoner may file without prepayment of 
28  2 

 
 
1  required fees.โ  Id. (citing 28 U.S.C. ยง 1915(g)).   
2  Here, it is clear the various claims raised against different defendants at SQSP are 
3  not all related to each other and do not all arise out of the same transaction, occurrence, or 
4  series of transactions or occurrences.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 20(a)(2).  โA buckshot complaint that 
5  would be rejected if filed by a free person โ say, a suit complaining that A defrauded 
6  plaintiff, B defamed him, C punched him, D failed to pay a debt, and E infringed his 
7  copyright, all in different transactions โ should be rejected if filed by a prisoner.โ  George 
8  v. Smith, 507 F.3d 605, 607 (7th Cir. 2007) (noting that, in prisoner complaint seeking to 
9  join 24 defendants and approximately 50 distinct claims, prisoner made no effort to show 
10  that 24 defendants he named had participated in the same transaction or series of 
11  transactions or that a question of fact is common to all defendants).  Accordingly, the 
12  Court finds that the claims against the named SQSP Defendants are improperly joined in 
a 
rt ni
ouor 13  this single action.  In the interest of justice, Plaintiff shall be granted leave to file an 
Cif
ct Cal 14  amended complaint containing only related claims against the appropriate Defendants.   
striof 
Dict  15  C.    Motion for Appointment of Counsel 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  Plaintiff has filed a motion for appointment of counsel based on indigency, the 
S 
ed ern 17  complexity of the issues, limited access to library and knowledge of the law, and that he 
th
nirt
UNo 18  would be better served by the assistance of counsel should this matter go to trial.  (Docket 
19  No. 4.)   However, there is no constitutional right to counsel in a civil case unless an 
20  indigent litigant may lose his physical liberty if he loses the litigation.  See Lassiter v. 
21  Depโt of Social Services, 452 U.S. 18, 25 (1981); Rand v. Rowland, 113 F.3d 1520, 1525 
22  (9th Cir. 1997) (no constitutional right to counsel in ยง 1983 action), withdrawn in part on 
23  other grounds on rehโg en banc, 154 F.3d 952 (9th Cir. 1998) (en banc).  The decision to 
24  request counsel to represent an indigent litigant under ยง 1915 is within โthe sound 
25  discretion of the trial court and is granted only in exceptional circumstances.โ Franklin v. 
26  Murphy, 745 F.2d 1221, 1236 (9th Cir. 1984).  Plaintiffโs asserted grounds do not establish 
27  exceptional circumstances.  Accordingly, the motion is DENIED for lack of exceptional 
28  3 

 
 
1  circumstances.  See Agyeman v. Corrections Corp. of America, 390 F.3d 1101, 1103 (9th 
2  Cir. 2004); Rand, 113 F.3d at 1525 (9th Cir. 1997); Terrell v. Brewer, 935 F.2d 1015, 1017 
3  (9th Cir. 1991); Wilborn v. Escalderon, 789 F.2d 1328, 1331 (9th Cir. 1986).  This denial 
4  is without prejudice to the Courtโs sua sponte appointment of counsel at a future date 
5  should the circumstances of this case warrant such appointment.

7  CONCLUSION

Accordingly, the third amended complaint is the operative complaint in this action.  The

1  Court will first conduct an initial screening of this third amended complaint below.   
2  Furthermore, Defendant Clawson has filed a motion to dismiss the third amended 
3  complaint without prejudice for Plaintiffโs failure to exhaust administrative remedies prior 
4  to filing suit.  Dkt. No. 32.1  Plaintiff filed an opposition with supporting documents in

6  For the reasons discussed below, Plaintiffโs third amended complaint is DISMISSED 
7  IN PART without leave to amend, and Defendantโs motion to dismiss is GRANTED with

9   
10  DISCUSSION 
11  I.    Initial Screening 
12  A.   Standard of Review 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  A federal court must conduct a preliminary screening in any case in which a 
Cfi
 tclaC 14  prisoner seeks redress from a governmental entity or officer or employee of a 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  governmental entity.  See 28 U.S.C. ยง 1915A(a).  In its review, the court must identify any 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  cognizable claims and dismiss any claims that are frivolous, malicious, fail to state a claim 
S de nre 17  upon which relief may be granted or seek monetary relief from a defendant who is immune 
th
intr
UoN 18  from such relief.  See id. ยง 1915A(b)(1),(2).  Pro se pleadings must, however, be liberally 
19 
 
20 
1 Under the law of the circuit, a motion for summary judgment under Rule 56 must be 
accompanied by a Rand notice so that the prisoner plaintiff will have fair, timely and

adequate notice of what is required of him in order to oppose the motion. Woods v. Carey,

for failure to exhaust available administrative remedies but only where a district court will

(9th Cir. 2012) (unenumerated Rule 12(b) motion to dismiss for failure to exhaust

where the district court will consider materials beyond the pleadings).  Here, Defendant

on the information provided in Plaintiffโs papers.  Accordingly, the Court finds no such

1  construed.  See Balistreri v. Pacifica Police Depโt, 901 F.2d 696, 699 (9th Cir. 1988).   
2    To state a claim under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983, a plaintiff must allege two essential 
3  elements: (1) that a right secured by the Constitution or laws of the United States was 
4  violated, and (2) that the alleged violation was committed by a person acting under the 
5  color of state law.  See West v. Atkins, 487 U.S. 42, 48 (1988). 
6  B.   Plaintiffโs Claims 
7  The underlying events took place at SQSP, where Plaintiff was formerly 
8  incarcerated.  Plaintiff claims that on or about August 14, 2018, he was beaten and battered 
9  by four inmates while he was waiting for his cell door to be unlocked after returning from 
10  evening meal.  Dkt. No. 29 at 4.  Plaintiff claims that Defendant Clawson discharged his 
11  weapon and shot Plaintiff in his lower back towards his buttocks, rather than the four 
12  intended targets, โwithout verbal warning.โ  Id.  As a result, the assailants failed to comply 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  and continued to assault Plaintiff.  Id.  Plaintiff claims that Defendant Clawson had pepper 
Cfi
 tclaC 14  spray in his possession, which was โless likely to relate to death or serious bodily injuryโ 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  but that he โdeliberately failed the use of alternatives to the immediate use of deadly forceโ 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  and acted with deliberate indifference when he shot Plaintiff with his block gun โto cause 
S de nre 17  [him] intentional injury, [and] damage.โ  Id. at 4.  Plaintiff claims Defendant Clawsonโs 
th
intr
UoN 18  actions were โunwarrantedโ because Plaintiff was the victim whom Defendant failed to 
19  protect from harm.  Id.  Plaintiff sues Defendant Clawson in his individual and official 
20  capacities and seeks damages as well as declaratory and injunctive relief.  Id. at 4, 7.  
21  Liberally construed, Plaintiff states a cognizable claim against Defendant Clawson under 
22  the Eighth Amendment for failure to protect.  See Farmer v. Brennan, 511 U.S. 825, 832 
23  (1994); Hearns v. Terhune, 413 F.3d 1036, 1041-42 (9th Cir. 2005).     
24  For the first time, Plaintiff names Warden Ron Davis as a defendant in this action, 
25  claiming generally that Defendant Davis โfailed in his duty to act upon notice, reports, 
26  appeals, and knowledge, promulgated a policy that does direct or condone the wrongful 
27 
 
28  3 

Case 5:18-cv-05558-BLF   Document 51   Filed 12/02/20   Page 4 of 13
 
 
1  conduct of defendant[] Clawson.โ  Dkt. No. 29 at 4.  Plaintiff also claims for the first time 
2  that the Director of the CDCR โis held liable for Warden Ron Davisโs actions, who are 
3  prison policymakers, writes regulations, or gives orders, at least for the purpose of prison 
4  management.โ  Id. at 4-5.  Based on these general allegations, Plaintiff is clearly 
5  attempting to hold the Warden and Director liable solely based on the acts of their 
6  subordinates and employees, which is not sufficient to state a claim.  However, his 
7  allegations are insufficient to support such a claim.    
8  First of all, under no circumstances is there liability under ยง 1983 solely because 
9  one is responsible for the actions or omissions of another.  See Taylor v. List, 880 F.2d 
10  1040, 1045 (9th Cir. 1989).  A supervisor may be liable under section 1983 upon a 
11  showing of (1) personal involvement in the constitutional deprivation or (2) a sufficient 
12  causal connection between the supervisorโs wrongful conduct and the constitutional 
 
a
tr in
uoro 13  violation.  Henry A. v. Willden, 678 F.3d 991, 1003-04 (9th Cir. 2012).  Even if a 
Cfi
 tclaC 14  supervisory official is not directly involved in the allegedly unconstitutional conduct, โ[a] 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  supervisor can be liable in this individual capacity for his own culpable action or inaction 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  in the training, supervision, or control of his subordinates; for his acquiescence in the 
S de nre 17  constitutional deprivation; or for conduct that showed a reckless or callous indifference to 
th
intr
UoN 18  the rights of others.โ  Starr v. Baca, 652 F.3d 1202, 1208 (9th Cir. 2011) (citation omitted).  
19  Plaintiff provides no specific allegations establishing that Warden Davis and the Director 
20  were personally involved in Defendant Clawsonโs failure to protect, nor has Plaintiff set 
21  forth any factual allegations establishing that these supervisor defendants engaged in 
22  specific wrongful conduct that is causally connected with the claim against Defendant 
23  Clawson.  See Henry A., 378 F.3d at 1003-04.  Nor has Plaintiff set forth any allegations 
24  establishing liability under the factors set forth in Starr, 652 F.3d at 1208.  If this 
25  inadequacy in pleading had occurred in Plaintiffโs original complaint, leave to amend 
26  might be considered.  However, leave need not be granted where the amendment of the 
27 
 
28  4

1  complaint would cause the opposing party undue prejudice, is sought in bad faith, 
2  constitutes an exercise in futility, or creates undue delay.  See Janicki Logging Co., 42 F.3d 
3  at 566; Roberts v. Arizona Bd. of Regents, 661 F.2d 796, 798 (9th Cir. 1981).  A district 
4  courtโs discretion to deny leave to amend is particularly broad where the plaintiff has 
5  previously filed an amended complaint.  Wagh v. Metris Direct, Inc., 363 F.3d 821, 830 
6  (9th Cir. 2003); Ferdik v. Bonzelet, 963 F.2d 1258, 1261 (9th Cir. 1992).  Plaintiff has had 
7  three opportunities to file an amended complaint, and before the Court is Defendantโs 
8  motion to dismiss for failure to exhaust administrative remedies.  Therefore, leave to 
9  amend to correct the deficiency in the claims against these supervisory defendants will not 
10  be granted as it would be futile, would create undue delay, and Plaintiff has already been 
11  granted several opportunities to file an amended complaint.  Accordingly, the claims 
12  against Defendants Davis and the Director are DISMISSED without leave to amend.

 tclaC 14  subsequent to the assault, asserting generally that the claims involve a different set of 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  defendants โall related to each other, arising out of the same transaction, occurrence, or
